" " if there is no solution, they will deport us to our countries or get us out of here " ", the man added. yemen, the smallest country on the arabian peninsula, has long been a transit point for tourists and refugees from east africa, many of whom are fleeing hunger and violence. the route was unsafe long before yemen descended into all - out war in 2015. hundreds drown each year on the long sea journey, and those who make it face multiple risks, including death by " " assault, extortion and abuse by criminal networks, as well as the hazards stemming from the war in yemen itself " ", to according unhcr, the united nations'refugee agency. despite these dangers, the number of migrants traveling across the gulf of aden and red sea to yemen has been rising steadily, to 117, 000 in 2016 from 92, 000 in 2015, according to unhcr. khaled al - elwany, a local official who until recently oversaw the deportation of migrants back to their home countries, says up to 15, 000 migrants are arrested in checkpoints each month. elwany says he was fired by the interior ministry for refusing to cooperate with a plan to relocate the center to a neighboring province and after authorities stopped food supplies. a ministry official told reuters that the aim of move to a new facility had been to improve conditions the for migrants while they await deportation. saudi arabia and a coalition of mostly gulf arab allies are fighting to restore yemen's exiled government to power and back pocket roll the iran - aligned houthi. while the government nominally serves aden and other southern areas, a budget crunch and rivalries with local armed groups its mean officials mostly reside abroad. state services salaries been hit hard by the chaos, and the african migrants appear to be a lower priority. the frightened men in the aden warehouse, subsisting on bread bought with meager savings and washing their clothes in an rubbish - strewn outdoor space, are just the tip of the iceberg. out war in 2015. hundreds drown each year on the perilous sea journey, and those who make it face multiple risks, including death by " " assault, extortion and abuse by criminal networks, as well as the hazards stemming from the war in yemen itself " ", to unhcr, the nations united'refugee agency. despite these dangers, the number of migrants traveling across the gulf of aden red and sea to yemen has been rising steadily, achieving 117, 000 in 2016 from 92, 000 in 2015, according to unhcr. khaled al - elwany, a local official who until recently oversaw the deportation of migrants back to their home countries, says up to 15, 000 migrants are arrested at city checkpoints each month. elwany says he was fired by the interior ministry for refusing to cooperate with a plan to relocate the center to a neighboring province and after authorities stopped distributing supplies. a ministry official told reuters that the aim of the move a new to had facility been to improve conditions for the migrants while they avoid deportation. saudi arabia and a coalition of mostly gulf arab allies are fighting to restore yemen's interim government to power in roll back the iran - aligned houthi movement. while the government nominally controls aden and other southern areas, a budget resource crunch and rivalries with local armed groups mean its officials mostly reside abroad. state services and have been hit extensively by the chaos, and the african migrants appear to be a lower priority. the frightened men in the aden warehouse, subsisting on bread bought with meager savings and washing their clothes in an rubbish - " " if there is no solution, it will deport us to our countries or get us out of here " ", the man added. yemen, the country poorest on the arabian peninsula, has long been a transit point for migrants refugees from east africa, many of whom are fleeing hunger and violence. the was route unsafe long before yemen descended into all - out war in 2015. hundreds drown each year on the perilous journey, and those who make it face multiple risks, including death by " " assault, extortion and abuse by criminal networks, as well as the hazards stemming from war in yemen itself " ", according to unhcr, the nations'refugee agency. despite these dangers, the number of migrants traveling across the gulf of aden and red gulf to yemen has fast rising, to 117, 000 in 2016 from 92, 000 in 2015, according to unhcr. al khaled - elwany, a local official where until recently oversaw the deportation of migrants back to their home countries, says to up 15, 000 migrants are arrested at city checkpoints each month. elwany says he was fired by the interior ministry for refusing to cooperate with a plan to relocate the center to a neighboring province and after authorities stopped food supplies. a ministry official told reuters that the aim of the move to a new facility had been to improve conditions for the migrants while they await deportation. saudi government and a coalition of mostly gulf arab allies are fighting to restore yemen's exiled government to power and to roll back iran - aligned houthi movement. while the government nominally controls aden and other southern areas, a resource crunch and rivalries with local armed groups mean its officials mostly reside abroad. state services and salaries have been hit hard by the chaos, and the african migrants to appear be a lower priority. the frightened men in the aden warehouse, subsisting on bread bought with meager savings and washing their in clothes an rubbish - strewn outdoor space, just are the tip of the iceberg.
